subsections.title: Newton’s First Law
subsections.content: This law states that an object will remain at rest or move in a straight line at constant speed unless acted upon by an external force.
points: Also called the Law of Inertia.
Objects resist changes in motion.
Example: A book on a table stays put unless pushed.

subsections.title: Newton’s Second Law
subsections.content: This law relates force, mass, and acceleration. It is expressed by the equation F = ma.
points: F = ma: Force equals mass times acceleration.
The greater the force, the greater the acceleration (if mass is constant).
Used to calculate force, mass, or acceleration in motion problems.

subsections.title: Newton’s Third Law
subsections.content: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
points: When object A exerts a force on object B, object B exerts an equal force in the opposite direction.
Example: A balloon moves forward when air rushes out the back.
Crucial in rocket propulsion and movement.

subsections.title: Definition of Friction
subsections.content: Friction is a force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact.
points: It can be static or kinetic.
It helps in walking and braking, but can also cause wear.

subsections.title: Types of Friction
subsections.content: There are several types of friction based on surfaces and motion.
points: Static friction: Prevents motion.
Kinetic friction: Opposes moving objects.
Rolling friction: Between rolling surfaces.
